bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, February 10, 1923

div1.p: Carter discusses the breeding habits of Stegomyia.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, February 10, 1923
div1.opener:
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.,
February 10, 1923.
Dr. Wickliffe Rose,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
Dear Doctor Rose:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of Feb. 9th., received to-day, en-
closing the “Datos acerca del Aedes calopus”, I would say:

1/ The insect is, I believe, by preference a day feeder, but
feeds both by day and night. Gorden and Young (at Manaos Laboratory:
Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine) by direct observation found
that with Stegomyia over 14 days old: 15 fed by daylight and 6 dur-
ing the same interval of time at night.

The hours selected were not, I think, especially favorable:
from 12.30 to 1.30 or from 1 to 2 for day feeding and from 8.30
to 9.30 at night. Had the daylight hour been--say--4 to 5 P. M. I
think the difference had been more marked than it was, but I think
that they were simply trying to comfute the dictum of the Commission
of the Pasteur Institute at Rio that Stegomyia old enough to be in-
fective never in nature “fed while the sun was above the horizon.”
(Annals of Tropical Medicine & Parasitology, Sept. 3/21: Page 265.)

The less well devised direct observations of Seidelin and Conal
(1914, as I recollect) give us the same finding--both day and night
feeding of old insects.

With regard to the exposure of the mosquitoes, in a glass tube, to
the sun: you will find an account of it in “Los Trabajos Selectos de
Carlos Finlay:” Pages 32 and 33, as occurring June 9/81 (I judge). I
suppose then it happened. Finlay was the soul of integrity--only the
word “despues” that Connor uses--meaning “after”--had been better
“mientras”--“during.”

McFie has, I think, given us the most reliable observations on
the upper limits of temperature compatible with the life of the Stego-
myia imago (and of the eggs: larvae and pupae as well)--using only
5 minutes exposure, however. For imagos he gives:--

“40° C.--profoundly affected, but not completely inactivated:
41° C.--Rendered inert:
41° C.--one half died--1/2 recovered:
44° C.--all died, 0 recovered.”

Finlay, himself, gives--Page 69: Op. cit.--15° C. to 37° C. or
38° C. as the limits of feeding. No one else has found them feeding
below 16°2/3 C. (Reed's Commission).

While she may be able to live a short time in hot sun, the Stego-
myia does not like it. She ever seeks the shade and partial darkness.
The wet bulb in Finlay's observation with the same exposure, but for
30 minutes instead of 15, showed 42.25 C. at which the insect should
not have been active and at which if continued she would have died.
This observation was made, apparently, with a single insect.

In his essentials for breeding places I could have wished that
Connor had formulated the general statement: “they have not been found
breeding completely (from oviposition to imago) in any collection of
water the sides of which at the water's edge were of mud.” It is, I
think, true for America, spite of General Antonelli's crab-holes in
Grand Bassam.
